title: Cherry — Tom Holland stars in a genre-busting crime drama
text:
The endless first-person voiceover that narrates the movie Cherry belongs to Tom Holland, cast as the ex-army medic of the title. The film — a genre-busting social realist/action movie/crime drama — adapts Nico Walker's 2018 autobiographical novel of service in Iraq, opioid addiction and subsequent bank robberies. A cynic might see the wholesale cut-and-paste as directors Joe and Anthony Russo drawing full value from the film rights. (Their production company paid $1m for those.) The truth feels less uncharitable. The Russos clearly love the book. Just as obviously, they are also film-makers noted for their work with Marvel — including the final two Avengers movies — now eager to make art. “Audio-visual entertainment”, a catty Martin Scorsese called the Marvel films. No director wants that on their grave.

The brothers cast Holland as their hero, the incumbent Spider-Man but also an actor good enough to lend Cherry depth. “I got a lot of sadness in my face,” he says, and that puppyish bearing is front and centre from the first-act origin story: a portrait of doomed youth in Cleveland, Ohio, heartbreak pending. But old habits die hard for the Russos, even in the absence of capes. While the backdrop is blue-collar, the movie comes with an expensive sheen of camera gymnastics, the editing made for the attention span in a hurry.

The sense of having it both ways turns queasy in Iraq. At the risk of sounding like Scorsese, even when it deals frankly with the charnel house reality of war, Cherry feels like a film made by the directors of Captain America: The Winter Soldier. The pity is that the strange marriage of the Russos and their material can also be fascinating. When Cherry's tour is over, a dustcloud clears to find him dazed in a high school gymnasium, medals doled out as Cleveland cheers. You can never go home again, the scene says, vividly.

But the other hallmark of the Marvel movie is how much of it there is. Here too the Russos stay true to form, the last hour of the film a long riff on junkie movies we have known before. Is all this an indictment, a j'accuse directed at big pharma? Or just the dope-life misadventures of one luckless dude? Don't ask Cherry. He's too busy talking to tell us.

★★★☆☆

On Apple TV+ from March 12
